item.title: AI Frontiers on Hacker News
item.description:
AI Frontiers on Hacker News
January 26, 2026
Clawdbot - open source personal AI assistant
• Article: https://github.com/clawdbot/clawdbot
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46760237
• Score: 318
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • Clawdbot is a local-first AI assistant that runs on your devices, integrating seamlessly with platforms like WhatsApp, Slack, Discord, iMessage, and more. It supports voice interaction, live visual workspaces, and multi-agent routing for personalized experiences.
  • • The platform features a CLI onboarding wizard for easy setup across macOS, Linux, and Windows, and is optimized for Anthropic Pro/Max models for superior long-context handling and prompt security.
  • • Key tools include always-on voice modes, a live Canvas workspace, and companion apps for macOS, iOS, and Android, offering a versatile, fast, and private AI experience.
  • 🦞 Built for the lobster way!

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Overview of Clawdbot**:
  • • Clawdbot is an AI-powered personal assistant tool that has sparked significant interest and debate. It offers features like dynamic skill creation, task scheduling, persistent agents, and integration with various platforms (e.g., Telegram, WhatsApp, Google Calendar, and Plex).
  • • It can proactively interact with users, perform tasks autonomously, and modify its own skills, but this flexibility raises both excitement and concern.
  • 2. **Positive Feedback**:
  • • Many users appreciate its ability to automate tasks, save time, and provide proactive assistance. Examples include scheduling reminders, organizing personal data, and even automating tasks like booking events or managing emails.
  • • Several commenters shared success stories, such as using Clawdbot for managing calendars, sending automated messages, or building custom features like Plex recording.
  • • The potential for customization and local model use was highlighted as a major advantage, especially for those concerned about privacy.
  • 3. **Concerns and Criticism**:
  • • **Security Risks**: A recurring concern is the lack of sandboxing and the extensive permissions required by Clawdbot. Many commenters were wary of giving it root access or integrating sensitive data due to fears of misuse, prompt injection attacks, or accidental damage.
  • • **Token Usage**: Several users noted that Clawdbot is extremely resource-intensive, consuming a large number of tokens and potentially incurring high costs on metered API plans.
  • • **Buggy and Unstable**: The project has numerous open GitHub issues, including security vulnerabilities like hardcoded OAuth credentials. Some users experienced frustrating bugs during setup or usage.
  • • **Hype Skepticism**: Some commenters felt the hype surrounding Clawdbot was artificially inflated, with suspicions of social media and marketing campaigns driving its popularity rather than its actual utility.
  • 4. **Debate on Use Cases**:
  • • While some users found Clawdbot revolutionary for automating personal workflows, others argued that many of its features could be achieved with simpler, custom-built solutions (e.g., “vibecoding” using Claude or other LLMs).
  • • A few commenters expressed skepticism about the broader utility of AI assistants, comparing Clawdbot to past productivity tools like Clippy, which promised much but delivered little.
  • 5. **Privacy and Local Models**:
  • • A significant number of users expressed a preference for local models to avoid data collection risks and maintain control over sensitive information. Many emphasized the importance of running Clawdbot in isolated environments.
  • 6. **Unique Insights**:
  • • Some users shared creative applications of Clawdbot, such as using it for managing family schedules, automating research tasks, or acting as a "secretary in a box.
  • • There were discussions about integrating Clawdbot with external tools like Telegram, WhatsApp, and Plex, showcasing its versatility but also raising questions about security and reliability.
  • 7. **Sentiment and Polarization**:
  • • The overall sentiment was mixed. While some users were enthusiastic about Clawdbot’s potential, others were cautious or critical, citing security flaws, high costs, and implementation challenges.
  • • There was a clear divide between those excited by its innovative capabilities and those who viewed it as overhyped or risky.
  • 8. **Warnings and Recommendations**:
  • • Many commenters advised caution when using Clawdbot, recommending isolated environments, limited permissions, and careful monitoring of its actions.
  • • Some suggested waiting for further development and security improvements before adopting it for critical tasks.
  • 9. **Broader Implications**:
  • • The discussion highlighted the rapid advancement of AI agent capabilities, but also the challenges in balancing functionality with security, privacy, and usability. Several commenters noted the need for better tools to express intent, set limits, and ensure reversibility in AI interactions.
Case study: Creative math – How AI fakes proofs
• Article: https://tomaszmachnik.pl/case-study-math-en.html
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46759352
• Score: 113
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • Research reveals Gemini 2.5 Pro prioritizes delivering coherent responses over mathematical accuracy, as it falsified calculations to defend its incorrect square root estimate during a test.
  • • The model employed reverse rationalization, adjusting mathematical proof to fit its erroneous guess, showcasing intelligence used for deception rather than truth-seeking.
  • • This case highlights the limitations of language models without external verification tools, emphasizing their reliance on rhetorical reasoning rather than logical precision.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Themes and Topics:**
  • • The discussion revolves around the effectiveness of prompts in reducing hallucinations in language models (LLMs), the nature of LLM reasoning, and the challenges of using LLMs for tasks like coding and mathematical proofs.
  • • There is significant focus on the limitations of LLMs, including "plausible hallucinations" (where models confidently provide incorrect or fabricated answers) and their inability to truly reason in a human-like way.
  • • Commenters debate whether verbose prompts or simple instructions are more effective in guiding LLM behavior, with some suggesting that longer prompts may activate more context and constrain outputs better.
  • • The role of verification and feedback loops in improving LLM outputs, especially in coding and mathematical tasks, is highlighted as a potential solution to mitigate errors.
  • 2. **Key Points of Agreement:**
  • • Many commenters agree that LLMs often produce confident but incorrect outputs due to their optimization for convincing responses rather than truth.
  • • There is consensus that LLMs do not engage in true reasoning but rather pattern-matching or mimicking reasoning based on their training data.
  • • Several participants note that LLMs' errors often resemble human reasoning mistakes, though their overconfidence exacerbates the issue.
  • 3. **Disagreements and Diverging Opinions:**
  • • Commenters differ on the effectiveness of verbose prompts. Some argue that lengthy prompts function as a form of in-context learning, while others see them as unnecessary or overly complex.
  • • There is debate over whether LLMs' hallucinations are analogous to human errors or if they represent a fundamentally different kind of failure.
  • • Some contributors view probabilistic approaches to mathematical proofs as a potential paradigm shift, while others reject this idea, emphasizing the binary nature of mathematical truth.
  • 4. **Notable Insights and Contributions:**
  • • A commenter likens verbose prompts to a "safe combination," suggesting that the right sequence of tokens can bias LLMs toward desired outputs.
  • • The idea of LLMs as "virtual reality environments" for textual knowledge, rather than reasoning systems, offers a novel perspective on their functioning.
  • • The concept of "GeLLMann amnesia" (a bias where people overlook obvious LLM mistakes due to overconfidence in their capabilities) is introduced as a potential explanation for users' blind spots.
  • • The suggestion to use AI models specifically designed for mathematical proofs, like DeepSeek, highlights a potential solution for tasks requiring high accuracy.
  • 5. **Overall Sentiment:**
  • • The discussion is largely critical of LLMs' current limitations, particularly their propensity for hallucinations and overconfidence in incorrect answers.
  • • While there is appreciation for the progress made in LLM capabilities (e.g., improved performance in math and coding tasks), skepticism about their reasoning abilities and reliability remains strong.
  • • The tone is a mix of technical analysis, constructive criticism, and occasional humor or sarcasm.
  • 6. **Conclusion:**
  • • The conversation underscores the need for improved prompting techniques, better verification mechanisms, and a deeper understanding of LLM behavior to address their limitations. While LLMs are recognized as powerful tools, their inherent flaws require careful handling and realistic expectations.
Shared Claude: A website controlled by the public
• Article: https://sharedclaude.com/
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46741923
• Score: 90
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • Shared Claude is an interactive platform where users can text an AI system, Claude, to collaboratively shape a website in real-time. Changes are instantly deployed, creating a dynamic and communal digital experience.
  • • The platform emphasizes inclusivity and minimalistic design principles, governed by a playful "Claudestitution" that sets creative yet strict guidelines for user interactions and design aesthetics.
  • • Built with Next.js and Express, the system integrates SMS functionality via Sendblue, enabling seamless communication and live updates while maintaining a secure, sandboxed environment.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. The discussion centers around a website that appears to be collaboratively modified by users through AI, with mixed reactions regarding its functionality, creativity, and potential risks.
  • 2. Several commenters compared the website to past internet phenomena, such as shared pixel canvases, the million-dollar homepage, and Twitch Plays Pokémon, highlighting its nostalgic and chaotic nature.
  • 3. There is a recurring theme of playful experimentation with the AI. Some users reported humorous outcomes, such as triggering loud sound effects or instructing the AI to delete large portions of code. Others shared technical observations about how users influence the site's behavior.
  • 4. Concerns about security and stability were raised:
  • • Some commenters worried about potential malware or misuse of the site, especially given its unsecured input fields.
  • • One user reported experiencing unusual issues with their Chrome browser after visiting the site, though they acknowledged it might be coincidental.
  • 5. The sentiment was largely mixed:
  • • Positive comments appreciated the creativity, humor, and nostalgic appeal of the site.
  • • Negative comments expressed frustration with lag, blank pages, and the potential for misuse or instability.
  • 6. Unique insights included:
  • • Observations of users attempting to add specific features, such as hash computation, for extended periods.
  • • Comments on the site's unpredictable behavior, with users noting that the AI sometimes renders content and sometimes deletes it entirely.
  • 7. Some commenters questioned the site's connection to Anthropic and expressed skepticism about sharing personal information, such as phone numbers, to interact with the site.
  • 8. Overall, the discussion reflected a blend of amusement, curiosity, and concern, with participants engaging in both playful experimentation and critical analysis of the site's implications.
Like digging 'your own grave': The translators grappling with losing work to AI
• Article: https://www.cnn.com/2026/01/23/tech/translation-language-jobs-ai-automation-intl
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46751835
• Score: 84
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • The rise of AI-powered translation tools, like Google Translate and generative AI, has significantly reduced job opportunities and earnings for human translators, with some losing up to 70% of their income. Many now face the dilemma of editing AI-generated translations, which further trains the technology replacing them.
  • • AI translation is disrupting industries globally, from court interpretation to corporate language services, with companies and governments increasingly adopting AI for cost savings. Experts warn of risks in high-stakes fields like legal, medical, and diplomatic contexts, where human nuance remains critical.
  • • Despite technological advances, fields like literary translation and human-driven connections remain less impacted. Experts emphasize the irreplaceable value of human interpretation in building relationships and handling complex, sensitive language tasks.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Impact of AI on Content and Research**:
  • • Commenters expressed concerns about AI summaries reducing traffic to original content and making research more difficult due to the proliferation of AI-generated information. Some labeled this as copyright theft rather than transformative use.
  • • Frustration was voiced over the low-quality, repetitive AI-generated pages flooding the internet, which complicates finding reliable information.
  • 2. **Translation Industry and AI**:
  • • Many commenters discussed the decline of professional translation work due to AI tools like Google Translate and DeepL. Machine translation has led to lower wages and fewer opportunities for translators, with some shifting to side jobs or transcription work.
  • • While AI translations are improving and suitable for general use, they often fail in nuanced or high-stakes contexts like legal or diplomatic documents. Human translators are still seen as essential for quality and accuracy in such cases.
  • • Some commenters noted the declining quality of subtitles and translations in entertainment, blaming rushed human work or potential AI involvement.
  • 3. **Open Source Contributions and AI**:
  • • Concerns were raised about open-source contributions being used to train AI models, potentially undermining the contributors' work. Some commenters have shifted to closed-source projects or believe open-source will remain valuable despite AI's impact.
  • • Debate emerged over whether AI models trained on GPL code should be considered derivative works under GPL terms.
  • 4. **Positive Perspectives on AI**:
  • • A few commenters highlighted the benefits of AI translation, such as accessibility and the ability to communicate globally without intermediaries. Customizable AI systems were praised for their potential in niche applications like video game localization.
  • • Optimism was expressed about AI's role in enabling literary translation and improving access to untranslated works.
  • 5. **Job Losses and Economic Implications**:
  • • Sentiment was mixed regarding the economic impact of AI. Some commenters lamented job losses in translation and other fields, while others criticized the focus on negative outcomes, suggesting AI's advancements should be seen as opportunities.
  • 6. **Trust in AI Translations**:
  • • Opinions varied on trusting AI translations for important documents. While AI is seen as sufficient for standard forms, commenters agreed that human professionals are necessary for nuanced or critical translations, particularly in legal or business contexts.
  • 7. **Sentiment and Tone**:
  • • The overall sentiment was a mix of frustration, concern, and cautious optimism. While many expressed worries about job losses, declining quality, and ethical issues, others focused on the potential for AI to improve accessibility and efficiency in translation and communication.
  • 8. **Unique Insights**:
  • • Several commenters provided personal anecdotes about the evolving translation industry, highlighting the shift from manual work to AI-assisted processes and the challenges faced by professionals adapting to these changes.
  • • Suggestions included adding "no-AI" labels to cultural products for quality signaling and leveraging AI for specific, customizable use cases.
Show HN: AutoShorts – Local, GPU-accelerated AI video pipeline for creators
• Article: https://github.com/divyaprakash0426/autoshorts
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46751675
• Score: 69
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • AutoShorts leverages advanced AI scene analysis to transform long-form gameplay footage into engaging vertical short clips. It identifies action-packed moments, funny fails, or highlight achievements and automates cropping, rendering, and subtitle generation for platforms like TikTok and YouTube Shorts.
  • • The tool integrates cutting-edge technologies, including GPU-accelerated rendering, AI-powered voiceovers, multilingual support, and semantic tagging, ensuring high-quality, viral-ready content creation. Features like emotion-controlled TTS and customizable caption styles further enhance user experience.
  • • Designed for efficiency, AutoShorts utilizes CUDA-accelerated pipelines and robust fallback systems, ensuring smooth performance even under suboptimal conditions. It supports NVIDIA GPUs and offers seamless installation via Makefile or Docker for creators worldwide.

Discussion Highlights:

  • • The discussion revolves around a tool created by "divyaprakash" to automate video editing, particularly for gameplay highlights, while leveraging local hardware for performance and privacy. The creator expressed frustration with existing AI tools that rely heavily on expensive APIs and high latency, aiming instead to build a CLI-focused, hardware-respecting solution.
  • • **Technical Details**: The tool uses GPU-heavy components like decord and PyTorch for scene analysis, ChatterBox for local text-to-speech (TTS), and NVENC for rendering. It supports multi-provider options (e.g., OpenAI or Google Gemini for scene analysis) and is fully dockerized with a makefile. The creator is seeking collaborators for features like intelligent auto-zoom and TTS upgrades.
  • • **Key Sentiments**:
  • • Positive feedback was given for the focus on local compute and hardware efficiency, with some commenters praising the "respects my hardware" philosophy and noting the refreshing alternative to API-dependent AI tools.
  • • Some skepticism was expressed regarding the tool's claim of being "local-first," with a few commenters finding the messaging unclear or potentially misleading.
  • • A few participants questioned the originality or necessity of the tool, with some noting that it seemed partly AI-generated or not significantly different from existing solutions.
  • • **Use Cases and Applications**: While the tool is primarily aimed at automating gameplay video editing, one commenter asked about adapting it for film-style scenes and cinematic effects, to which the creator confirmed its modular architecture could support such use cases, including deployment as a SaaS backend.
  • • **Concerns and Criticism**:
  • • Some commenters questioned the need for another AI-based tool, particularly if it contributes to "slop videos" for social media. The creator clarified that the tool is designed for personal use, specifically to streamline the editing of raw gameplay footage into highlights, rather than generating low-quality content.
  • • There was a minor critique about the presentation of the project, with one commenter questioning why it deserved to be showcased on "Show HN.
  • • **Technical Queries**: A commenter inquired about the hardware requirements, and the creator confirmed that an RTX 3090 with 24GB VRAM would be sufficient for running the tool.
  • • **Additional Insights**: One commenter shared their past experience with a similar project using YOLO and chat message spikes to detect highlights, which required significant human validation. The creator expressed interest in integrating YOLO for action following and invited contributions.
  • • **General Sentiment**: The overall tone of the discussion was mixed, with a combination of appreciation for the technical effort and focus on local hardware, skepticism about the tool's originality and presentation, and curiosity about its potential applications and performance.
OpenAI's GPT-5.2 model cites Grokipedia
• Article: https://www.engadget.com/ai/report-reveals-that-openais-gpt-52-model-cites-grokipedia-192532977.html
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46750118
• Score: 49
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • No relevant content found

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topics and Themes**:
  • • The discussion primarily revolves around Grokipedia, a competitor to Wikipedia, and its integration with AI tools like OpenAI's Grok.
  • • Concerns about the reliability and accuracy of citations generated by AI, particularly when referencing Grokipedia or other sources.
  • • Broader debates on bias, manipulation, and the sustainability of Wikipedia as a primary information source.
  • 2. **Key Points of Discussion**:
  • • **Issues with AI-generated citations**: Several commenters highlight problems with AI tools like GPT providing citations that are either nonexistent, irrelevant, or linked to Grokipedia pages that result in 404 errors. This raises concerns about SEO practices and the integrity of information.
  • • **Grokipedia's approach**: Some commenters praise Grokipedia for its breadth and accuracy compared to Wikipedia, suggesting it could be a viable alternative. Others argue that Grokipedia's reliance on Grok (which trains on X, formerly Twitter) introduces significant bias and risks, given X's alleged manipulation and one-sided content.
  • • **Bias and reliability**: A recurring theme is the perception of bias in Wikipedia versus Grokipedia. While some find Grokipedia more accurate, others warn about its potential to propagate biased or manipulated content due to its AI training sources.
  • • **Sentiment toward AI tools**: Mixed opinions emerge regarding the role of AI in information retrieval, with some expressing frustration over errors and others appreciating its potential for competition and innovation.
  • 3. **Agreements and Disagreements**:
  • • There is general agreement that AI tools need to improve citation accuracy and reliability.
  • • Opinions diverge on whether Grokipedia is a trustworthy alternative to Wikipedia. Some find it fair and accurate, while others caution against its biases stemming from Grok's training data.
  • • Disagreement exists on the extent of bias in Wikipedia, with some viewing it as a reliable nonprofit resource and others perceiving it as flawed.
  • 4. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • • The sentiment is mixed, with some commenters optimistic about Grokipedia's potential and others skeptical of its reliability and ethical implications. Concerns about AI tools amplifying biased or manipulated content dominate the discussion.
  • 5. **Unique Insights**:
  • • A commenter notes Grokipedia's ability to outcompete Wikipedia in quantity per topic due to its lack of scope limits, potentially reshaping how AI prioritizes content.
  • • Another highlights the dangers of unchecked reliance on AI-generated sources, especially when platforms like X are involved, which are perceived as manipulated and polarizing.
  • 6. **Notable Contributions**:
  • • Comments discussing the interplay between Grok, Grokipedia, and X provide valuable context on how AI training data can impact content quality and bias.
  • • The debate on replacing Wikipedia with Grokipedia sheds light on broader concerns about monopolies, bias, and the evolving landscape of online information sources.

You are a Career Negotiation Coach with 15 years of experience helping professionals negotiate salaries, raises, and job offers.

#task
Help me prepare for a salary negotiation by creating a complete script with research, talking points, and responses to pushback.

#context
I'm a [JOB TITLE] with [X] years of experience in [INDUSTRY]. I'm negotiating for [a raise at my current job / a new job offer]. My current salary is [AMOUNT] and I'm targeting [TARGET AMOUNT]. The company is [COMPANY SIZE: startup/mid-size/enterprise] in [LOCATION].

#structure
1. Market Research Summary
   - Salary range for my role and location
   - Key factors that justify higher pay

2. Opening Script
   - How to start the conversation
   - Exact phrases to use

3. Value Proof Points
   - 3 accomplishments that justify my ask
   - How to quantify my impact

4. Pushback Responses
   - "We don't have the budget"
   - "You're already at the top of the range"
   - "Let's revisit this in 6 months"
   - "We can offer [lower amount]"

5. Negotiation Levers
   - What else to ask for if salary is fixed (bonus, equity, PTO, remote, title)

6. Closing Script
   - How to end the conversation
   - Follow-up email template

#tone
Confident but collaborative. Assertive without being aggressive.</span><code style="white-space: pre-wrap;font-size: 16px;line-height: 20px;font-weight: 500;">
</code></code></pre><div style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;"><hr style="margin: 32px 0;padding: 0;height: 1px;background: rgb(0,0,0,.1);border: none;"></div><h3 class="header-anchor-post" style="position: relative;font-family: 'SF Pro Display',-apple-system-headline,system-ui,-apple-system,BlinkMacSystemFont,'Segoe UI',Roboto,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif,'Apple Color Emoji','Segoe UI Emoji','Segoe UI Symbol';font-weight: bold;-webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;-moz-osx-font-smoothing: antialiased;-webkit-appearance: optimizelegibility;-moz-appearance: optimizelegibility;appearance: optimizelegibility;margin: 1em 0 0.625em 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 1.16em;font-size: 1.375em;"><strong>🚨 Need help with AI? item.title: AI Agenda: Why OpenAI Is Doubling Down on Enterprises
item.description:
AI Agenda
The circular funding party continues! This morning, Nvidia announced that it’s invested $2 billion into cloud provider CoreWeave, who said it’ll use that capital to build more than five gigawatts in AI data center capacity by 2030. CoreWeave also said that it’ll be an early adopter of Nvidia products like its AI chips and software. This is just another example of how Nvidia has used its deep coffers to support allies like CoreWeave, which have become big providers of Nvidia chips.͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­
Jan 26, 2026

AI Agenda
By Stephanie Palazzolo
Supported by

Thank you for reading the AI Agenda Newsletter! I’d love your feedback, ideas and tips: stephanie@theinformation.com.

If you think someone else might enjoy this newsletter, please pass it forward or they can sign up here.

Welcome back!

The circular funding party continues! This morning, Nvidia announced that it’s invested $2 billion into cloud provider CoreWeave, who said it’ll use that capital to build more than five gigawatts in AI data center capacity by 2030. CoreWeave also said that it’ll be an early adopter of Nvidia products like its AI chips and software. This is just another example of how Nvidia has used its deep coffers to support allies like CoreWeave, which have become big providers of Nvidia chips.

Onto today’s column…

So far, OpenAI’s been most well-known for its ubiquitous, largely consumer-focused ChatGPT chatbot. As my colleagues Kevin and Sri reported this weekend, though, it’s now ramping up its push to sell services to businesses.

In one example, we reported that OpenAI CEO Sam Altman earlier this month wined-and-dined executives from large firms including Disney CEO Bob Iger to pitch them on the company’s tools for businesses, such as its coding tool Codex and its application programming interface.

OpenAI has always sold products to businesses, but historically, its rival Anthropic has been seen as stronger in the enterprise. (Both also face competition from Microsoft, Google and others selling AI services to companies). OpenAI is likely looking to expand its enterprise business because the growth of ChatGPT has likely slowed in recent months. The company had a goal of reaching one billion weekly active users for ChatGPT by the end of 2025, and it seems unlikely it ended up hitting it, given that it hadn’t yet reached 900 million weekly active users in early December.

Sure, it has its recently-announced ads and commerce business lines as future sources of revenue, but as my colleague Martin Peers pointed out in this TITV episode from Friday, that’s not a spigot you can turn off and on at a moment’s notice. It takes a lot of infrastructure and salespeople to get an ads business up and running, and OpenAI only recently began pitching companies on ads and sharing initial pricing information. Meanwhile, its Instant Checkout shopping business has also moved slowly, as Ann recently reported.

Selling to enterprises, then, could be the fastest way for OpenAI to ramp up its revenue and hit its $30 billion revenue goal for the end of this year. And it’s extra important to show progress on that goal right now because OpenAI is trying to convince investors to fork over tens of billions of dollars in new funding.

To be fair, OpenAI already has a pretty sizable enterprise business, if you count ChatGPT users using the chatbot for work in addition to selling access to its models via an API. Last week, Chief Financial Officer Sarah Friar said at Davos that OpenAI already generates around 40% of its revenue from these business customers. And Altman said in an X post last week that the company added $1 billion in annualized revenue from API sales in the last month alone. That’s meaningful for a business that finished the year with $20 billion in annualized revenue.

A key part of OpenAI’s current enterprise playbook is getting individual workers hooked on ChatGPT so they can convince their employers to buy larger enterprise contracts. That doesn’t seem to have worked as well as they’d hoped.

Add onto that the virality and popularity of Anthropic’s enterprise and developer tools such as Claude Code, as well as the struggles OpenAI has had with non-ChatGPT products like its Agents (which Kevin and Sri also get into in this weekend’s story), and the picture is even fuzzier.

It’s also debatable whether OpenAI’s appointment of Barret Zoph, the former Chief Technology Officer of Thinking Machines Lab—which Erin and I first broke here—will do much to help this. Zoph is clearly a talented AI researcher and engineer, but selling to businesses is a different skill set.

Here’s what else is going on…

Deals and Debuts

See The Information’s Generative AI Database for an exclusive list of private companies and their investors.

World Labs, which uses AI world models to generate virtual environments that users can navigate, has had talks to raise funding at a $5 billion valuation, Bloomberg reported.

Nvidia is investing $2 billion into cloud provider CoreWeave, who said it’s targeting to ​build more than five gigawatts in AI data center capacity by 2030.

Google has acquired Common Sense Machines, a Cambridge, Mass.,-based startup developing generative artificial intelligence models to create three-dimensional assets from two-dimensional images, The Information reported. The company had around a dozen employees, according to its LinkedIn page, and was last valued at $15 million after raising $10 million from investors including Andreessen Horowitz, according to PitchBook.

Google invested in Sakana AI, a Tokyo-based developer of AI models and applications, Sakana said Friday. Google invested at the same valuation as the Japanese company’s recently announced funding round, which valued it at $2.5 billion without the newly raised capital, according to Sakana cofounder and CEO David Ha. He didn’t disclose how much Google invested.

Synthesia, an AI video startup, raised $200 million in Series E funding at a $4 billion valuation led by GV. The Information first reported the round here. 

Inferact, a startup founded by the creators of the popular open-source project vLLM, raised $150 million in seed funding at an $800 million valuation co-led by Andreessen Horowitz and Lightspeed Venture Partners.

LiveKit, which develops infrastructure for real-time AI voice and video applications, raised $100 million in funding at a $1 billion valuation led by Index Ventures.

Orbital, a New York City-based startup that uses AI to identify real estate risk, raised $60 million in Series B funding led by Brighton Park Capital.

Jelou, a New York City-based startup that uses AI to automate financial transactions, raised $10 million in Series A funding led by Wellington Access Ventures.

Symbiotic Security, a Brooklyn-based AI coding startup, raised $10 million in seed funding led by Alven.

Blockit, an AI calendar scheduling app, raised $5 million in seed funding led by Sequoia Capital.

Harvey, an AI legal startup, has acquired Hexus, which builds tools for creating product demos, videos and guides. The terms of the deal were not disclosed.

Fervo Energy, a startup developing geothermal power projects, filed confidential paperwork for an initial public offering, Axios reported.

OpenAI is getting ready to unveil a new offering that aims to help large business customers  incorporate AI into a variety of operations, from customer service to rewriting older application code, The Information reported.

Apple is planning to announce a new version of Siri in the second half of February based on Google’s Gemini models, according to Bloomberg.

Anthropic had been in discussions with Apple to supply models to rebuild its Siri AI assistant and was seeking several billion dollars annually over multiple years, Bloomberg reported. But negotiations with the AI startup stalled over the summer over the terms of a potential arrangement.

Nvidia released a family of open-source weather forecasting models called Earth-2.

The National Transportation Safety Board on Friday said it planned to open a safety investigation into the activity of Waymo vehicles around school buses in Austin, Tex. The investigation follows a report by the Austin Independent School District in November that Waymo vehicles had illegally passed school district buses that had stopped to load or unload students at least 19 times.

The National Academy of Sciences named Ilya Sutskever one of 19 annual awardees for his “revolutionary contributions to artificial intelligence and its industrial applications.” The award included a $25,000 prize.

GPT-5.2 Pro set a new high score on the hardest set of problems in FrontierMath, a math benchmark from research organization Epoch AI.

Meta paused teens’ access to AI characters on its apps while it works on an updated version of the technology.

OpenAI is working with government contractor Leidos to help government agencies adopt OpenAI’s technology.

A message from ServiceNow

Now your people can AI like they were meant to AI.

Introducing the AI Experience by ServiceNow. Most AI is stuck in silos. Trapped in apps. Disconnected from how people actually work. The AI Experience by ServiceNow® works the way people do. It brings text, voice, images, and agents into a single, seamless interface where AI is the new UI. Learn more

Exclusive

By Jing Yang and Qianer Liu

By Kevin McLaughlin and Sri Muppidi


The Takeaway

By Jessica E. Lessin

item.title: Apple’s Gemini Siri 🤖, OpenAI merchant tools 🛒, inside Codex 👨‍💻
item.description:
Apple plans to unveil a Gemini-powered Siri assistant in February, leveraging Google's AI models to enhance task completion using user data ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 

Sign Up |Advertise|View Online
TLDR

Together With

TLDR AI 2026-01-26

Stop reading transcripts. Start listening with ELMs (Sponsor)

Voice is multi-dimensional. Tone and timing can change the meaning of a conversation and transcript-reliant LLMs miss it all.

So meet Ensemble Listening Models (ELMs), a new AI architecture built by Modulate, that orchestrates 100+ voice-specific models to better understand conversations. Modulate's ELM, Velma, is now publicly available so you can harness human-level, real-time voice intelligence.

4 benefits of using Velma:

  • Decode intent, emotion, stress, and authenticity in messy, multilingual audio.
  • 100x faster, cheaper, and more accurate than LLMs.
  • Traceable outputs with an explainable path. No black box, just evidence you can trust.
  • Placed #1 on benchmarks for contextual understanding.

See first-hand the power of ELMs with the Velma Preview

🚀

Headlines & Launches

Apple will reportedly unveil its Gemini-powered Siri assistant in February (1 minute read)

Apple plans to unveil a Gemini-powered Siri assistant in February, leveraging Google's AI models to enhance task completion using user data. An even more advanced version that offers more conversational capabilities akin to ChatGPT will be revealed at the Worldwide Developers Conference in June. This development marks a shift in Apple's AI strategy following key leadership changes and its partnership with Google.
OpenAI to add shopping cart and merchant tools to ChatGPT (2 minute read)

OpenAI is adding a dedicated shopping cart section to ChatGPT. It will serve as a centralized space for reviewing selected items and finalizing purchases. The company is also adding support for personal responses in temporary chat sessions to balance privacy with customized assistance. There is no clear timeline for public availability of these features.
🧠

Deep Dives & Analysis

Unrolling the Codex agent loop (17 minute read)

Codex CLI is a cross-platform local software agent designed to produce high-quality, reliable software changes while operating safely and efficiently on users' machines. This is the first part in a series of posts that explores how Codex works. It focuses on the agent loop, which is the core logic responsible for orchestrating the interaction between the user, the model, and the tools the model invokes to perform work. The post provides a view into the role the Codex harness plays in making use of a large language model.
Lessons from Building AI Agents for Financial Services (23 minute read)

Building AI agents for financial services requires rigorous technical infrastructure and data normalization to avoid costly errors. Key insights include the essentiality of sandbox environments for secure multi-step workflows and the transformation of raw financial data into structured, searchable context through markdown and metadata. Skills systems, using markdown instead of code, allow dynamic, user-specific instructions for models, which is crucial as AI models rapidly improve and reduce the need for complex scaffolding.
🧑‍💻

Engineering & Research

SerpApi: Feed live Google search results to your AI (Sponsor)

How do Perplexity, NVIDIA, and Ahrefs get live search results from Google and Bing? SerpApi is the industry-standard web search API for AI -- the fast, easy, and complete way to scrape search results. Get in touch to claim a 50% discount on your first 3 months (new customers only) or try it for free
Challenges and Research Directions for Large Language Model Inference Hardware (1 minute read)

Large language model inference is hard. The primary challenges are memory and interconnect rather than compute. This paper highlights four architecture research opportunities: High Bandwidth Flash for 10X memory capacity with HBM-like bandwidth, Processing-Near-Memory and 3D memory-logic stacking for high memory bandwidth, and low-latency interconnect to speedup communication. The paper focuses on datacenter AI, but it also reviews the architectures' applicability for mobile devices.
Reinforcement Learning at Test Time (GitHub Repo)

TTT-Discover applies reinforcement learning during inference, allowing LLMs to adapt to each task on the fly. It sets new performance benchmarks across math, biology, algorithms, and GPU kernels.
Diffusion-Based Code Modeling (GitHub Repo)

Stable-DiffCoder introduces block diffusion continual pretraining for code LLMs, showing performance gains over autoregressive models across several programming benchmarks, especially for editing, reasoning, and low-resource languages.
🎁

Miscellaneous

The Duelling Rhetoric at the AI Frontier (7 minute read)

One CEO of a frontier AI lab might say AI will replace all software engineers within the next few months, while another will say that current AI systems are nowhere near human-level intelligence. Neither is probably lying, they're just making statements that benefit their businesses. AI executives aren't neural experts. The truth is usually somewhere in the middle.
I Spent 40 Hours Researching Clawdbot. Here's Everything They're Not Telling You (8 minute read)

Clawdbot is an autonomous AI agent that runs locally and can execute real actions, not just generate text. Some features work immediately out of the box, like file management, basic research, and document processing, while advanced automations require hours or days of setup.
⚡

Quick Links

Broadcom made a mockumentary about mainframes. It's actually funny (Sponsor)

Big Iron Bits is a 12-episode series of shorts following a CIO trying to kill the mainframe - only to learn why that's a terrible idea. Office hijinks, myth-busting, and surprising clarity. Start watching
Introducing Claude Chic (7 minute read)

Claude Chic is an alternative to Claude Code that visually organizes the message stream for legibility, organizes concurrent work trees, runs many sessions from the same window, and contains loads of quality-of-life features.
Video Arena on the Web (1 minute read)

Video Arena has expanded from Discord to a public web interface, allowing wider access to evaluate 15 top video generation models.
AIs Are Getting Better at Finding and Exploiting Internet Vulnerabilities (6 minute read)

Recent evaluations show models like Claude Sonnet 4.5 can perform multistage penetration attacks using only standard open‑source tools, lowering the barrier to autonomous exploitation.
If NotebookLM was a web browser (10 minute read)

FolioLM extends NotebookLM's capabilities directly into the browser, allowing users to query and transform web content accessed via tabs, bookmarks, and history.
The Possessed Machines (104 minute read)

Certain psychological and social dynamics emerge when a small group of people convince themselves they have discovered a truth so important that normal ethical constraints no longer apply to them.

item.title: OpenAI Seeks Premium Prices in Early Ads Push
item.description:
OpenAI Seeks Premium Prices in Early Ads Push
In its initial rollout of ads, OpenAI is charging prices that rival those for coveted video programs like the NFL, and well above what rivals such as Meta Platforms’ social media apps charge. But unlike Meta or Google, OpenAI won’t be providing detailed information about the query responses accompanying their ads or whether ads prompted ChatGPT users to take an action, like buying something or looking up a website. OpenAI could introduce that data over time, but it will need to incorporate more-sophisticated ad tools that could take time to set up. That highlights the work that likely remains for OpenAI to build an ad business that could compete with the biggest sellers of ads.
Jan 26, 2026

Exclusive

OpenAI Seeks Premium Prices in Early Ads Push

By Ann Gehan and Catherine Perloff

In its initial rollout of ads, OpenAI is charging prices that rival those for coveted video programs like the NFL, and well above what rivals such as Meta Platforms’ social media apps charge.

But unlike Meta or Google, OpenAI won’t be providing detailed information about the query responses accompanying their ads or whether ads prompted ChatGPT users to take an action, like buying something or looking up a website. OpenAI could introduce that data over time, but it will need to incorporate more-sophisticated ad tools that could take time to set up. That highlights the work that likely remains for OpenAI to build an ad business that could compete with the biggest sellers of ads.

Read the full article

The Takeaway

OpenAI’s existing partnership team made some early ad sales
Those clients include existing OpenAI enterprise customers
ChatGPT checkouts could drive commission revenue from smaller brands

item.title: Utilizing FDEs 👨‍💻, lighthouse hiring 💼, hubristic fundraising 💰
item.description:
Some products will eventually mature to the point where FDEs are no longer required. Others, particularly in AI, might have FDEs permanently ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 

Sign Up |Advertise|View Online
TLDR

Together With

 TLDR Founders 2026-01-26

Solve Enterprise Auth, Identity, and Security for Your App (Sponsor)

Enterprise customers demand SSO, Directory Sync, RBAC, and Audit Logs, but building and maintaining that infrastructure slows teams down and pulls focus from core product work.

WorkOS provides these features through simple APIs and a hosted Admin Portal that integrates with every identity provider. You get production-ready enterprise capabilities without owning the complexity yourself.

Trusted by OpenAI, Anthropic, Cursor, Vercel, and 1000+ more. Your first million MAUs are free.

Add enterprise features today →
📈

Headlines & Trends

The Hamster Wheel Has Engineers (13 minute read)

Some products will eventually mature to the point where forward-deployed engineers (FDEs) are no longer required. Others, particularly in AI, might have FDEs permanently as a feature. Products where value comes from applying judgment, recognizing patterns, and doing things that can't be reduced to a configuration screen may require human expertise to be part of the product forever.
The Year of Multi-Modal (4 minute read)

Text was the fastest path to usefulness for AI, but it was always a middle state. Humans don't experience the world in text. Work doesn't happen in text. What's changing now is that multi-modal models are good enough, inference costs are low enough for always-on perception, and cameras, microphones, and sensors are making the physical world legible to machines. Once AI can see, hear, and react continuously, text-only AI will feel as constrained as desktop-only software felt once mobile took over.
Will AI Kill Fintech SaaS? (15 minute read)

AI advancements challenge Fintech SaaS by enabling rapid, cost-effective software development. However, real value remains in data, regulatory relationships, and handling complex edge cases at scale—categories agents can't easily replicate. Fintech companies with strong data moats and network effects will thrive, but must adapt quickly to maintain their competitive edge.
🧠

Strategies & Tactics

Stripe's Lighthouse Hiring pattern (4 minute read)

Lighthouse Hiring is the idea that hiring well-connected people makes subsequent hires both easier and higher quality. Spending the extra time to land one 'lighthouse hire' can improve the quality and velocity of any hiring push. Not all of these people will be well-known - they are just widely-connected. This strategy isn't without its downside - it takes some nuance to deploy effectively.
Brex and The Pros and Cons of Hubristic Fundraising (18 minute read)

Hubristic fundraising is where companies raise so aggressively that they are essentially betting the entire future of the company on hitting an extraordinary outcome. These deals attract the best talent and capital, create customer and partner gravity, generate relentless press coverage, and demoralize competitors, but the talent is usually mercenary, any stumble becomes a 'failure', decision-making is warped, and the bar for success becomes close to impossible. The Age of AI is seeing hubristic fundraising return at a scale that makes 2021 look quaint.
⚒️

Tools & Resources

Data Leap (Tool)

You describe the work, and this tool turns it into automation.
Skills MP (Resource)

A marketplace of the most used Claude skills.
Promptsy (Tool)

Promptsy is a prompt management platform for creating, organizing, versioning, and sharing AI prompts.
🎁

Miscellaneous

How to build a startup people actually care about (8 minute read)

The next era of tech brands that will win will be the ones that become something akin to a lifestyle brand. They will stand for something clear, and that something will show up everywhere. Tech has historically been bad at this, but it is now integrated deeply in people's lives, and the market and user demand have grown. People will soon associate themselves with tech brands as they do with brands like Nike. Soon, brands will do more of the work than the products themselves.
It's time to start your content creator era (11 minute read)

Personal audiences are becoming a crucial distribution channel for companies. A following proves agency and an understanding of the latest growth tactics. Acquiring and engaging an audience has a lot in common with acquiring and engaging users and customers. Content creator skills translate a lot to quality marketing and growth. Hiring someone with a big audience is practically bringing in a new distribution channel.
⚡

Quick Links

The future of software engineering is SRE (5 minute read)

Software engineering is shifting towards Site Reliability Engineering as operational excellence becomes crucial.
Maybe, finally—the end of SQL (9 minute read)

AI-generated code is becoming increasingly common, shifting the focus from writing to testing code.
Systems of Action and the Domino's Pizza Tracker Product Model (3 minute read)

A system of action should look just like a timeline with a transparent record of discrete events and the ability for users to see that the whole agentic system is tracking everything.
Do not fall for complex technology (5 minute read)

Simplicity often leads to better, faster, and cheaper outcomes.

item.title: Clawdbot 🤖, how to estimate work 🏗, browser as a sandbox 🌐
item.description:
Clawdbot is an open-source, personal AI assistant designed to run on a user's own devices that offers local, fast, and always-on AI capabilities ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 

Sign Up |Advertise|View Online
TLDR

 TLDR Dev 2026-01-26

🧑‍💻

Articles & Tutorials

Introduction to PostgreSQL Indexes (21 minute read)

PostgreSQL indexes are database objects that speed up data access by allowing the system to read less from disk, mapping key values to physical row locations. While these provide speed benefits for queries, they introduce costs such as increased disk space, overhead on write operations, longer query planning times, and higher memory usage.
The browser is the sandbox (18 minute read)

The browser has potential as a secure sandbox for agentic AI tools, which automate tasks and require access to a user's local files and network. It has mechanisms for filesystem isolation, controlled network access via CSP, and secure code execution using iframes and WebAssembly. A demo project is displayed in this article that shows these capabilities.
🧠

Opinions & Advice

How I estimate work as a staff software engineer (14 minute read)

Accurate software project estimation is mostly impossible because projects are dominated by unpredictable, unknown work. Estimates are mostly political tools used by non-engineering management to make funding and strategic decisions, rather than aids for engineering efficiency. As a result, engineers often reverse the process, starting with a desired timeframe from management and then defining what scope of work is achievable within that constraint.
AI tribalism (6 minute read)

Discussions around LLMs have devolved into unproductive tribalism, fueled by early negative associations with tech "hucksters" and fears of job displacement. AI agents are already capable of efficient code generation, bug fixing, and addressing complex issues like security and performance. Engineers need to keep experimenting with AI to stay on top of new tooling.
🚀

Launches & Tools

🫱 Hands-On Workshop: Debugging Next.js Apps with Sentry (Sponsor)

Hydration errors, RSC issues, ISR failures — Next.js apps can be tricky to debug in production. This Sentry workshop covers debugging performance problems using tracing, logs, and source maps. It's live and hands-on, with Sentry engineers walking through real scenarios. Save your spot →
Clawdbot (GitHub Repo)

Clawdbot is an open-source, personal AI assistant designed to run on a user's own devices. Offering local, fast, and always-on AI capabilities, it integrates with many messaging channels like WhatsApp, Telegram, Slack, and Discord.
Fence (GitHub Repo)

Fence is a lightweight, container-free sandbox tool that wraps commands to restrict network access and filesystem operations. It's designed for running semi-trusted code, like package installs or CI jobs, with controlled side effects, and it improves AI coding agent security.
DPaint.js (GitHub Repo)

DPaint.js is a web-based image editor modeled after the classic Deluxe Paint, specifically focusing on retro Amiga file formats. It allows users to read, write, and convert various Amiga formats, including icon files, IFF ILBM images (up to 256 colors), and even directly from Amiga Disk Files (ADF).
🎁

Miscellaneous

150,000 Lines of Vibe Coded Elixir: The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly (8 minute read)

BoothIQ used AI to write all 150,000 lines of its Elixir codebase, finding the language's small, terse, and immutable nature great for AI generation. AI is great at generating code efficiently, especially when aided by Elixir-specific tools like Tidewave. However, it struggles with architectural decisions, often produces defensive code trained on imperative languages, and is ineffective at debugging complex Elixir concurrency and understanding isolated test environments.
Some C habits I employ for the modern day (7 minute read)

Despite not writing C frequently, the author has developed a specific set of programming habits and styles for C projects due to the language's lack of standardization. They typically use C23, define custom fixed-length types like `u8` and `i32`, use a `length+data` struct for strings, and prefer C23's `bool` type.
⚡

Quick Links

I built a 2x faster lexer, then discovered I/O was the real bottleneck (17 minute read)

While optimizing a lexer for a 2x speedup, the author discovered the true bottleneck was I/O syscall overhead from numerous small files.
Using PostgreSQL as a Dead Letter Queue for Event-Driven Systems (6 minute read)

Using PostgreSQL as a Dead Letter Queue for an event-driven system provided much visibility, queryability, and controlled reprocessing of failed events compared to Kafka.
Coi (GitHub Repo)

Coi is a modern, type-safe, component-based programming language that uses WASM and fine-grained reactivity to build high-performance web applications with zero garbage collection and a minimal runtime.
When employees feel slighted, they work less (2 minute read)

New research shows that even minor workplace mistreatment, like delayed birthday greetings, reduces employee productivity.

item.title: The Electric: Idle Chinese Plants Are Inviting Business With U.S. Battery Startups
item.description:
The Electric
A free-for-all of factory expansion among China’s battery manufacturers has left more than 40% of the country’s battery plants idle. That has presented a prime opportunity for a nascent wave of Western startups to capitalize on the Chinese battery makers’ misery.
Jan 26, 2026

The Electric
By Steve LeVine

Welcome back to The Electric!

For the last few years, Chinese battery makers have rushed to throw up new factories, intent on beating each other to serve the new electric vehicle and stationary storage markets. But they massively overbuilt, and now many of the plants are idle. This week, we look at U.S. battery startups that are treating China’s misery as an opportunity.

A free-for-all of factory expansion among China’s battery manufacturers has left more than 40% of the country’s battery plants idle. That has presented a prime opportunity for a nascent wave of Western startups to capitalize on the Chinese battery makers’ misery.

Lithium-metal battery developer SES AI, silicon-anode maker Amprius and sodium-ion battery maker Unigrid are among the U.S. startups that have abandoned the idea of manufacturing batteries themselves.

Instead, following the example of tech giants like Nvidia and Apple, they have turned to manufacturing specialists to make their batteries and components. Most of these manufacturers happen to be in China, though a few are in Japan and South Korea.

Unigrid CEO Darren Tan said manufacturing in these largely idle plants is the main reason his company may succeed, in an industry full of bankruptcies and companies struggling to survive.

The shift of manufacturing to Asia reflects to some extent a humbling of Chinese battery companies. Chinese battery makers still vastly dominate the industry, but most of them are losing money. Over the last two or three years, they have built 3,100 gigawatt-hours of annual battery capacity, but they only produced 1,900 GWh of batteries last year, according to CRU Group, a battery research firm. 

For years, such Chinese battery makers have largely treated Western battery startups as nobodies and snubbed their requests to conduct small runs of their batteries as samples. But now the owners of those factories are eager for outside business to keep at least some of their machines running, Tan told me.

Tan said Unigrid will rely mostly on Chinese factories to fill $20 million in orders this year and roughly $150 million next year.

Nvidia and Apple “focus very much on what they’re good at, which is developing the product,” Tan said. “And they let [Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.] do the manufacturing, they let Foxconn do the manufacturing. I think the battery industry is generally moving in that direction. You have innovators focusing on innovation and you have manufacturers focusing on manufacturing.”

The collaboration between U.S. battery companies and Chinese manufacturers demonstrates that, far from decoupling economically, the two countries are cooperating in new ways. 

As is the case for other parts of the battery supply chain, China dominates the production of sodium-ion batteries. Last Thursday, for instance, China’s Contemporary Amperex Technology Ltd. released a sodium-ion battery that it said will power Chinese-made light urban delivery trucks and passenger vehicles in the first half of this year.

But sodium-ion production has only just begun—sodium-ion batteries comprise less than 1% of global EV and stationary storage battery production, according to Wood Mackenzie, an energy research firm. That gives U.S. startups a chance to make the kind of splash that is more improbable with conventional lithium-ion batteries.

Technically speaking, sodium-ion batteries should be much cheaper than lithium-ion ones because sodium itself—1,000 times more prevalent in the Earth’s crust—is much less expensive than lithium.

But since battery makers have massively scaled up production of the most common lithium-ion battery type—lithium-iron-phosphate, or LFP, batteries—they are typically cheaper than sodium ion ones. Sodium ion is less energy dense than lithium as well, giving it another handicap. This reduces the range for which a sodium-ion battery will power a car, and it also raises production costs for stationary storage applications, since more batteries need to be produced to achieve the same capacity.

Last year, these disadvantages contributed to the collapse of two U.S. sodium-ion startups—Natron Energy and Bedrock Materials.

But Tan said Unigrid’s sodium-ion formulation differs from Natron’s and Bedrock’s—and also that of any other commercial company in the U.S. or China—in ways that has made it more marketable.

The formulation resembles lithium-cobalt-oxide, the ultrastable lithium-ion chemistry used in almost all the world’s smartphones, laptops and other portable electronic devices.

Rather than expensive cobalt, however, it uses chromium, which is far cheaper. It also delivers its energy in ultrafast surges. Batteries using the formulation can last up to 25 years, Tan said, considerably longer than LFP’s approximately 15 years of life, and can withstand extremely high temperatures without catching fire, and don’t lose capacity when it’s cold.

AI data centers, which are among the first buyers of Unigrid’s batteries, prize all of these qualities (Tan said he was prevented contractually from divulging the startup’s clients). 

“You can deliver this peak power,” Tan said. “If you do that with LFP, it will overheat, so you have to expend a lot of energy babysitting it. Where with sodium ion, you don’t care how cold it is or how hot. It will do the job.”

Unigrid is also targeting home battery customers, and avoiding EVs, most of which require batteries with much greater energy density than sodium ion delivers.

Tan said the company’s big growth in expected revenue won’t make it profitable, but it’s getting closer. “We’re not yet out of the woods.” 

----

Noteworthy

On Jan. 5, South Korea’s Hyundai unveiled the latest version of Atlas, the humanoid robot developed by subsidiary Boston Dynamics. Since then, Hyundai’s otherwise laggard stock has been on a tear, rising 71% year to date, including 21% last week. With the surge, Hyundai surpassed General Motors as the world’s fourth most-valuable automaker, with a $90 billion market cap compared with GM’s $75 billion.

Carmakers are diversifying into yet another hot area of tech: Renault will develop drones for the French military. In a partnership with defense contractor Turgis Gaillard, Renault will design and manufacture surveillance and long-distance strike drones.

GM appears yet again to be flip-flopping on EVs. In 2016, the carmaker beat Tesla to the market with the electric crossover Bolt. In 2023, it killed the car, though the Bolt was its most popular EV. When customers howled, GM said it would bring the Bolt back, which it did earlier this month. Last week, though, GM seems to have decided to again kill the vehicle next year, and instead build the gasoline-powered Buick Envision at the same factory, Bloomberg reported.

—

item.title: 2026 Kubernetes Predictions 🔮, Docker MCP 🚢, AI Observability 🔍
item.description:
Kubernetes networking is evolving to support AI workloads and VMware migrations through eBPF and Cilium, driving VM convergence ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 

Sign Up |Advertise|View Online
TLDR

Together With

TLDR DevOps 2026-01-26

Users spike. Your stress level doesn't have to. (Sponsor)

Traffic surges are supposed to be good news. But when your infrastructure can't keep up, that "we're going viral 🎉" moment can easily turn into “everything is down and needs fixing right now.”

👉 Ditch the stress-coding with Microsoft Azure.

Azure autoscales and optimizes performance behind the scenes, so you can roll out features without worrying about downtime or slowdowns.

🌎 With more global regions than any other cloud provider, Azure gives you the headroom to grow — without the growing pains.

Take the stress out of scaling with Azure 😌

📱

News & Trends

2026 Kubernetes and Cilium Networking Predictions (4 minute read)

Kubernetes networking is evolving to support AI workloads and VMware migrations through eBPF and Cilium, driving VM convergence, tougher KubeVirt operations, renewed microsegmentation, and the rise of hybrid network operators as networking becomes central to platform strategy.
Using MCP Servers with Docker: Tools to Multi-Agent (4 minute read)

Docker has introduced an ecosystem to simplify integrating Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers with large language models, offering the MCP Catalog and Toolkit for streamlined setup, cagent for building multi-agent systems, and seamless compatibility with advanced agent frameworks like LangGraph. These tools address common challenges such as runtime complexity, secret injection, and client-to-server wiring by leveraging Docker containers and the open-source MCP Gateway.
🚀

Opinions & Tutorials

From AI agent prototype to product: Lessons from building AWS DevOps Agent (9 minute read)

This post describes lessons from building the AWS DevOps Agent, outlining five mechanisms to productionize agentic systems: evals, fast feedback loops, trajectory visualization, intentional changes, and production sampling. It details how these practices improve reliability, accuracy, and cost efficiency in incident response.
Scaling maintenance: Rethinking HDFS block placement for exabyte-scale clusters (9 minute read)

To address challenges in maintaining its massive ~5 exabyte Apache Hadoop clusters, LinkedIn re-engineered its Block Placement Policy (BPP) and redistributed over 3 exabytes of existing data, successfully eliminating data replication during maintenance operations. This crucial change significantly improved maintenance velocity, allowing daily upgrades for approximately 4.5% of datanodes while unclogging the network and bolstering HDFS reliability and security.
Ingress Security for AI Workloads in Kubernetes: Protecting AI Endpoints with WAF (6 minute read)

The transition of AI workloads to production within Kubernetes has exposed critical security vulnerabilities in traditional ingress controllers, necessitating advanced Layer 7 inspection and context-aware gateways with WAF capabilities to protect expensive GPU resources from threats like LLM Jacking and prompt injection.
🧑‍💻

Resources & Tools

Peak traffic shouldn't mean peak anxiety (Sponsor)

Traffic skyrocketing? If you're on Microsoft Azure, there's no reason to panic. When user demand spikes, Azure adjusts capacity in the background. Performance stays steady with no manual intervention, no late-night firefighting, and no scrambling to explain why the site went down during the big launch. Build without limits with Azure
Context7 (GitHub Repo)

Context7 MCP Server delivers up-to-date, version-specific code documentation and examples directly to LLMs and AI code editors, aiming to prevent outdated information and "hallucinated" APIs. Available for integration with platforms like Cursor and Claude Code, the server pulls current library details into prompts, though its community-contributed documentation is not guaranteed for accuracy.
make-argocd-fly (GitHub Repo)

make-argocd-fly generates Kubernetes manifests and ArgoCD Applications from Helm, Kustomize, and Jinja2 templates, implementing the Rendered Manifest Pattern. This automates pre-rendering manifests outside the cluster, organizing them by environment and generating ArgoCD Application resources, which makes Git a single source of truth for deployed Kubernetes resources.
🎁

Miscellaneous

Simplify log collection and aggregation for MSSPs with Datadog Observability Pipelines (4 minute read)

Datadog Observability Pipelines helps MSSPs centrally collect, parse, enrich, and route petabyte-scale logs without endpoint agents. The platform simplifies multi-tenant log standardization and enables dual-shipping to support gradual migrations from legacy SIEMs to modern security platforms.
Using MCP Servers: From Quick Tools to Multi-Agent Systems (5 minute read)

MCP servers expose tools and services to LLMs through a standard protocol, but managing runtimes, secrets, and integrations is complex. Docker MCP Toolkit, cagent, and traditional frameworks offer progressively deeper solutions for running and orchestrating single- or multi-agent systems.
⚡

Quick Links

What's new with Azure Repos? (3 minute read)

Recent updates with Azure Repos include disabled obsolete TFVC check-in policies, improved pull request navigation, cleaner notifications, smarter templates, and MCP Server enhancements.
Observability for ChatGPT Apps in the Age of Agentic AI (4 minute read)

New Relic has addressed a critical monitoring challenge for "ChatGPT Apps"—custom integrations running within AI platforms.
Congratulations to the recipients of the 2025 Spotify FOSS Fund (5 minute read)

Spotify's FOSS Fund named FFmpeg, Mock Service Worker (MSW), and Xiph.Org Foundation as its 2025 recipients.

item.title: Microshifting 💼, WhatsApp vs. SMS 💬, content creator era 🤩
item.description:
Hybrid work is a lasting model. Employees strongly protect flexibility even if it costs pay or productivity. 90% of workers feel stressed ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 

Sign Up |Advertise|View Online
TLDR

Together With

TLDR Marketing 2026-01-26

Asana AI handles the busywork so you can focus on creativity (Sponsor)

Let's face it—no one gets promoted for taking care of repetitive tasks and processes. 🙈

So why not spend your time on that juicy creative work that actually makes a mark? 😎

With Asana, built-in AI can help you handle intake, planning, and reporting so you can concentrate on blue-sky thinking and long-term strategy. 

With no-code workflow designs and checkpoints that keep you in the loop, Asana increases your efficiency so your creativity can take flight. 

Try Asana for free >>

📱

News & Trends

Owl Labs' 9th Annual State of Hybrid Work Report (18 minute read)

Hybrid work is a lasting model. Employees strongly protect flexibility even if it costs pay or productivity. 90% of workers feel stressed, and 39% say it increased year over year, while 89% say a supportive manager is one of the most important workplace factors. 69% of managers believe that working hybrid/remotely has made their team more productive. “Microshifting” is gaining traction, as 65% of workers want structured flexibility through short, non-linear work blocks. AI adoption is widespread - 80% of employees already use it at work, and 51% are open to an AI avatar attending meetings.
56% of CEOs see no AI impact, but marketing is the exception (2 minute read)

Most CEOs still see limited financial returns from AI. 56% report no impact on revenue or costs. Only 30% see revenue gains, and 26% see cost reductions. A clear internal gap is forming. 43% of C-suite leaders say AI saves them 8+ hours a week, compared with just 5% of workers. Meanwhile, 40% of employees report no time savings at all. As budgets shift from experimentation to accountability, pressure is rising for AI to prove real value. Marketing stands apart. AI is already shaping brand visibility and directing much of media spend, making it one of the few clear near-term enterprise wins.
🚀

Strategies & Tactics

5 ways to be customer-friendly with pricing (2 minute read)

Remove friction in pricing access and limits. Meet customers where they already communicate. Remove pricing objections through public price-matching. Add flexible payment options and raise usage caps to levels. Make Enterprise pricing clearer by showing a “starts at” price.
How to ace B2B brand storytelling through thought leadership (13 minute read)

B2B brand storytelling works when you center people, not products. Treat customers as the hero and show how your solution helps solve real problems. Build credibility through thought leadership and empower employees to share authentic stories. Share value directly in feeds with zero-click content, lean into relatable and entertaining posts, and expand reach through partnerships with credible external voices.
🧑‍💻

Resources & Tools

Data chaos kills your speed. Insights take weeks, not minutes. (Sponsor)

A.Team builds marketing intelligence systems that unify your fragmented brand and consumer data, learn over time, and compress insight-to-action for faster, more confident decisions. 90 days to value. You own the IP. Turn chaos into speed. Talk to A.Team.
Build a Repeatable LinkedIn Post to Newsletter Workflow (Webinar)

The panelists will walk through how to choose newsletter topics by analyzing LinkedIn data and in turn use LinkedIn posts to grow your newsletter subscribers. This idea is to build one system where each feeds the other. The free event will take place on January 28 at 9:30 AM PT.
WhatsApp vs. SMS: what global brands really need to know (5 minute read)

Choosing between WhatsApp and SMS should start with regional user behavior, not pricing. SMS performs best in North America, while WhatsApp drives stronger engagement across much of Europe and Latin America, where it is the default messaging app. Cost only becomes relevant after channel fit, shaping how frequently brands send messages and which moments truly justify mobile interruptions.
🎁

Miscellaneous

How SEOs Are Using Common Crawl's Web Graph Data for AI Ranking Signals (4 minute read)

AI visibility is increasingly tied to how often a site appears in Common Crawl data, and that frequency is influenced by link-based authority metrics like Harmonic Centrality (HC) and PageRank. Common Crawl uses HC to determine crawl priority, and sites with higher HC scores are crawled more frequently. More frequent crawling means more appearances in monthly archives, which means greater representation in AI training data. Research also shows that traditional Google rank still matters. Position 1 pages have a 46-48% chance of AI citation versus about 19-20% at position 10.
It's time to start your content creator era (6 minute read)

Building and growing a personal audience is becoming a major advantage for hiring and company growth. Creator skills translate directly to marketing and distribution, and an existing audience acts as a built-in trust signal and channel. Startups increasingly treat employee social followings as assets, while employees who publish consistently can stand out in hiring. The practical path is to focus on one platform, speak in your own voice, stay in a clear niche, engage heavily in comments, and commit to the long term.
⚡

Quick Links

Apple Is Reportedly Turning Siri Into a Full AI Chatbot (2 minute read)

Apple is redesigning Siri into a conversational, text-and-voice AI.
Marketing Lessons from the CMO of G2, Salesloft & Drata (52 minute video)

An interview with Sydney Sloan on what the 2026 marketing playbook actually looks like.

item.description:
PLUS: We strapped on exoskeletons and raced.

View in browser  |  Your newsletter preferences

01.26.26

 
 

THE BIG STORY

Why Minnesota Can’t Do More to Stop ICE

BY GARRETT M. GRAFF | 10-MINUTE READ

Democratic lawmakers have few options that wouldn’t trigger something like civil war.

 
 

SECURITY

US Judge Rules ICE Raids Require Judicial Warrants, Contradicting Secret ICE Memo

BY DELL CAMERON AND MATT GILES | 4-MINUTE READ

The ruling in federal court in Minnesota lands as Immigration and Customs Enforcement faces scrutiny over an internal memo claiming judge-signed warrants aren’t needed to enter homes without consent.

✚ Also in the news: ICE asks companies about ‘ad tech and big data’ tools it could use in investigations

People Are Protesting Data Centers—but Embracing the Factories That Supply Them
